puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Can you explain a bit the need for this onlyif?

If we don't protect with this validation the puppet-agent will run over all port elements in platform::interfaces::sriov::sriov_config. The enabling consists of zeroing and applying the new sriov_numvfs value.
If we just do that to all ports of the list, unnecessarily, the zeroing will erase all existing bindings, and this will reflect on the pods using the "netX" interface (it will disappear)
The logic only ensures that the value is applied if there is a change

I wonder if this can be cleaned up to remove the duplicate code on lines 273->275.  I think we could remove the $runtime and $config_vf parameters altogether if done correctly.  Basically, there would be a platform::interfaces::sriov::config (for example) that did the driver binding and vf rate setting.  Another class could be platform::interfaces::sriov::enable (for example) that simply creates the platform::interfaces::sriov_enable resources.  Then, the platform::interfaces::sriov::runtime would call into the 'enable' class.  The platform::interfaces::sriov::vf::runtime would call into both the 'enable' and 'config' classes.  Thoughts?

I reorganized to have platform::interfaces::sriov responsible to make the config data accessible, Both classes (enable and config) are now available
In order to execute the necessary configuration during boot the class worker.pp is now pointing to platform::interfaces::sriov::config instead of platform::interfaces::sriov

The default backend for manila is the "generic" driver - it's pretty heavy for a qualification job like this. We have some other easier/friendlier alternatives. Could we consider one of those? Manila has two classes of drivers DHSS=True and DHSS=False [1]. For an easier, simpler experience to start testing these jobs with DHSS=False - the testing behavior changes slightly, but manila tempest plugin will handle some things for you so there is no difference between user expectations. 


Choices for DHSS=False drivers that are easy to set up are: LVM, ZFSOnLinux, CephFS (native or NFS). I would suggest using LVM. The options you could use to setup LVM are here: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/9efbc94e963613a617631d27917ba278429566f5/zuul.d/manila-tempest-jobs.yaml#L162-L204 

Not all of those options are required. We can do with this part: https://github.com/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/blob/9efbc94e963613a617631d27917ba278429566f5/zuul.d/manila-tempest-jobs.yaml#L173-L183



[1] a bit of context about DHSS: It stands for "driver_handles_share_servers". It's a driver mode when set to True would allow users to get their shares exported directly on their isolated project networks (or any network they choose) - this involves the back end storage system drivers creating "share servers" to perform this exporting - this mode provides hard network path multi-tenancy isolation guarantees as opposed to DHSS=False. I believe this is not accurate.

The MAC learning capabilities introduced recently in OVN are precisely to avoid sending traffic to all ports with addresses field set to 'unknown'. Instead, OVN will avoid flooding by learning which port in the Logical Switch the destination MAC address is connected and sending the traffic only to that port.

Prior to v21.03, the behavior would be to flood all traffic to all the 'unknown' ports with a potential performance hit and unwanted network traffic if the number of such ports is large.
I think you are right here, thanks!

swift/common/db.py.message:
maybe this is more correct - but the existing tests don't make it obvious

I guess if you have 30 tombstones and a a reclaim_page_size of 10 you expect 3 queries to pull 10 each and the last one to be empty?

yes, that's what I'd expect.

But on master you have 2 clean_batch_qry queries deleting 11 row and a final one that deletes 9 rows (assuming the rows are all reclaimable) with a RECLAIM_PAGE_SIZE of 10.

I found it confusing that the RECLAIM_PAGE_SIZE is not the size of the "batch" implied by clean_batch_qry.

test/unit/account/test_backend.py.message: so we should have 30 containers and 30 tombstones
it's not obvious to me at all why this number is more correct, but I can see there's an extra (4 total) _reclaim call with the size of 10.

it's not "more" correct - it's just the number of rows reclaimed per call to _reclaim that you need in order to have reclaim complete in 3 calls to _reclaim with the given scenario i.e. this gives you batches of 11, 11, 9. To get the same batch sizes on master we needed RECLAIM_PAGE_SIZE of 10.

Any batch size between 11 and 15 will result in 3 calls to _reclaim. Batch size 10 results in 4 calls to _reclaim because the 3rd call returns an end_marker, necessitating a 4th call to discover that there are no more rows. The test assert 3 calls to _reclaim, so the batch size needs to be adjusted to satisfy that.

specs/approved/uefi-pxe-boot-from-volume.message:
I'm confused, the expectation and what is coded is to chain load into an ipxe loader binary. This is known to work on x86_64 and I' believe based on some discussions should also work on aarch64 with a UEFI image build.

In UEFI cases, the binary doesn't *need* network interface card drivers, but are supposed to use the UEFI primitives for networking which does require that the card support UEFI as well. Obviously, if that is not the case, then it doesn't work.

 - User could want to just use benefit of this role refactor, but really don't want to reconfigure his current haproxy configuration.

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/main.yml.message: nit: for some reason ansible shows group_by tasks as changed, although nothing on the remote hosts has actually changed. In kayobe I proposed adding changed_when: false to group_by tasks.

Well, I agree with you, but in fact there are new groups created - from ansible view, so actually there is a change.

But yes, agree this should be green ...but if this will be changed to "changed_when: false" , I would prefer to change it also in whole kolla-ansible.

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/recover_clus.message: I expect this will need to be per-shard.
Have you tested the recovery command with multiple clusters? I expect it would need to recover all clusters simultaneously, rather than just one?

If I remember, i tested ..but I will not put my hand in the fire for that.
Will try again.
Working, you can limit hosts if you want to only one.
To be clear, the task will work, but only one file will be removed, for the shard of the host that runs the task.

This is still broken with multiple shards. It only removes the file belonging to one shard. If there are others they will be left.

Either we need to find all values of mariadb_recover_tmp_file_path and remove those files, or use find module with a prefix and remove matching files.

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/register.yml.message: This task will run once, so only one shard's user will be created.
Agree, sorry :) , i've already noticed that.
The code has changed since this version to remove run_once :)

I think these tasks should now run per shard instead.
Similarly, we need to handle backups per shard, no?

Well, I admit that I do not use backup from kolla, but from playbook it is visible that it is connecting to database_address (which is VIP proxysql) and login user special mariadb_shard_database_user ..so proxysql route it to proper shard ..

Having two users with root privileges per cluster might make some people nervous. Would it make sense to remove the normal root account for sharded clusters? Or use the option 'Disallow root login remotely?' during mysql_secure_installation?
Of course, I can remove root user ..but you should not affect users which potentionally can have some scripts with root user.
Indeed. Another option is to lock down the root_* users privileges, but that would prevent admins getting a full privilege account to any shard via proxysql.

ansible/roles/mariadb/tasks/sharding.yml.message: Running this simultaneously on multiple hosts in the same shard is asking for a race condition in the Ansible module :)

No problem, the include is guarded with

inventory_hostname == groups[mariadb_shard][0]

ansible/site.yml.message: Please factor out into a playbook and import, similar to how gather-facts.yml works.

releasenotes/notes/mariadb-role-install-.message: This is an implementation detail. From the user's perspective, they just care that it allows them to create multiple clusters.
Again, focus on clusters rather than groups.

TBH, these are not really issues that would affect users on upgrade, since they won't have customised new variables. This is almost a mini-documentation on the feature. I suggest we just remove the upgrade section.

ansible/roles/ovn/tasks/bootstrap.yml.message: Given that these tasks run on every host, it might be nice to collapse them into one, and reduce a list of key/values down to those that are required.
Could be a follow up. I'm just concerned about performance, now that we have expanded one of these tasks into a 4 item loop.
Hopefully setting to empty is the same as removing.

Not removing, ovn-cms-options is a string with options delimited by , - if it's empty, then there are no additional options (and it's in the default schema). It might lead to an issue if somebody sets it to some user defined value - it will be overridden here.

Previously this was only done in this case:

  when:
    - inventory_hostname in groups["ovn-controller-network"]
      or (inventory_hostname in groups["ovn-controller-compute"] and computes_need_external_bridge | bool)

Given the new conditions on the import, this could be reduced to:

inventory_hostname in groups["ovn-controller-network"] or computes_need_external_bridge | bool

This applies to the whole task. It should only apply to the bridge mappings.

You could add a 'when' field to each dict.
Are you sure it doesn't need | bool here?
No (works fine), but actually I will rework when: into state: - because with when: it will just skip and with state: it will clear it out on unwanted hosts after some configuration changes.

I think it's unnecessary, but shouldn't hurt.
Well right, we shouldn't have a node in ovn-controller group, if there's no openvswitch on it.

avoid depends-on for the same repo (not sure if this even works, at least last time i tried it was inconclusive)

it doesn't seem to complain here i.e. the wallaby content provider is run OK

But generally when you have 2 changes that are dependent but in the same repo, you should just post one on top of the other instead of using depends-on. In other words, this change should have just been rebase onto https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/785219

perhaps there are better docs but from quick search found some info on cross-repo depends-on there https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/developers.html#cross-repository-dependencies

zuul.d/content-provider.yaml.message: I understand we have copied Victoria example,  but out of curiosity wondering why we needed master here? Is it for upgrade jobs.

Right ykarel... @Sandeep we need it for that bit: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/785179/2/zuul.d/multinode-jobs.yaml#156 

where we want the wallaby provider to run for master branch in changes to tripleo-quickstart/tripleo-quickstart-extras

now having said that, we are only running the _master_ template there right now https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/commit/31d1492a1378806b2328480525fc4216cb34a57c/zuul.d/layout.yaml#L10 ... which means we aren't running any of the stable/branch content providers (any more, we used to)...  https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/src/commit/77e31fc928097459840845a1fbd6012c74eb5091/zuul.d/upgrades-jobs-templates.yaml#L5

so *strictly* speaking we could probably remove the 'master' match on these, but I'd rather wait until the upgrades jobs upstream situation is a bit more clarified during/after PTG (i.e. our effort of moving all the check/gate upgrades jobs into periodic/3rd party lines)
As this job will run against master in unbranched CI projects and stable/wallaby in branched projects.
